claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

verified_evidence.quote: The manufacturing process can lead to egg adapted mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) protein in IIV, that could result in altered antigenicity and differences in vaccine effectiveness (VE) in the population.
verified_evidence.explanation: The quote appears in the first paragraph of the document, though with some minor OCR artifacts and word breaks. The relevant sentence is: 'manufacturing process can lead to egg adapted mutations in themagglutinin (HA) protein in IIV, that could result in altered an ...iff i (VE) i h i l i'. Despite the OCR issues, the meaning is preserved: the manufacturing process can lead to egg-adapted mutations in the HA protein in inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV), which could result in altered antigenicity and differences in vaccine effectiveness (VE) in the population.. The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that the manufacturing process (specifically for egg-based vaccines) can lead to egg-adapted mutations in the HA protein, which could alter antigenicity and result in differences in vaccine effectiveness. This matches the claim that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
verified_evidence.presence_explanation: The quote appears in the first paragraph of the document, though with some minor OCR artifacts and word breaks. The relevant sentence is: 'manufacturing process can lead to egg adapted mutations in themagglutinin (HA) protein in IIV, that could result in altered an ...iff i (VE) i h i l i'. Despite the OCR issues, the meaning is preserved: the manufacturing process can lead to egg-adapted mutations in the HA protein in inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV), which could result in altered antigenicity and differences in vaccine effectiveness (VE) in the population.
verified_evidence.support_explanation: The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that the manufacturing process (specifically for egg-based vaccines) can lead to egg-adapted mutations in the HA protein, which could alter antigenicity and result in differences in vaccine effectiveness. This matches the claim that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
verified_evidence.original_relevance: This quote directly states that the manufacturing process for egg-based vaccines can cause mutations in the HA protein, which may change the antigenic properties of the vaccine and impact its effectiveness, supporting the claim about mutation development and reduced effectiveness.

verified_evidence.quote: Repeat vaccination with egg based influenza vaccines could preferentially boost antibodies targeting the egg adapted epitopes and reduce immunogenicity to circulating viruses.
verified_evidence.explanation: The quote 'Repeat vaccination with egg based influenza vaccines could preferentially boost antibodies targeting the egg adapted epitopes and reduce immunogenicity to circulating viruses.' appears verbatim in the document, near the beginning of the main text. The only differences are minor formatting/spacing, but the factual content and meaning are identical.. The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that repeat vaccination with egg-based influenza vaccines can preferentially boost antibodies to egg-adapted (i.e., mutated during production) epitopes, and that this can reduce immunogenicity to circulating viruses. This means that mutations arising during egg-based vaccine production can lead to immune responses that are less effective against the actual circulating strains, thus potentially reducing vaccine effectiveness. This is exactly what the claim asserts.
verified_evidence.presence_explanation: The quote 'Repeat vaccination with egg based influenza vaccines could preferentially boost antibodies targeting the egg adapted epitopes and reduce immunogenicity to circulating viruses.' appears verbatim in the document, near the beginning of the main text. The only differences are minor formatting/spacing, but the factual content and meaning are identical.
verified_evidence.support_explanation: The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that repeat vaccination with egg-based influenza vaccines can preferentially boost antibodies to egg-adapted (i.e., mutated during production) epitopes, and that this can reduce immunogenicity to circulating viruses. This means that mutations arising during egg-based vaccine production can lead to immune responses that are less effective against the actual circulating strains, thus potentially reducing vaccine effectiveness. This is exactly what the claim asserts.
verified_evidence.original_relevance: This statement explains that repeated use of egg-based vaccines can enhance immune responses to egg-adapted (mutated) epitopes rather than those on circulating viruses, implying that such mutations can reduce the vaccine's effectiveness against actual circulating strains.

verified_evidence.quote: Vaccine egg adapted changes had the most impact on A (H3 N2) immunogenicity.
verified_evidence.explanation: The quote 'Vaccine egg adapted changes had the most impact on A (H3 N2) immunogenicity.' appears verbatim on page 1 of the document: 'We performed an exploratory analysis. Vaccine egg adapted changes had the most impact on A (H3 N2) immunogenicity.' The wording and meaning are preserved.. The quote directly states that egg-adapted changes (mutations that occur during egg-based vaccine production) had the most impact on the immunogenicity of the A (H3 N2) influenza strain. This supports the claim that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines can develop mutations during production that may reduce their effectiveness, as immunogenicity is a key component of vaccine effectiveness. The document explicitly links egg-adapted changes to altered immune responses, substantiating the claim.
verified_evidence.presence_explanation: The quote 'Vaccine egg adapted changes had the most impact on A (H3 N2) immunogenicity.' appears verbatim on page 1 of the document: 'We performed an exploratory analysis. Vaccine egg adapted changes had the most impact on A (H3 N2) immunogenicity.' The wording and meaning are preserved.
verified_evidence.support_explanation: The quote directly states that egg-adapted changes (mutations that occur during egg-based vaccine production) had the most impact on the immunogenicity of the A (H3 N2) influenza strain. This supports the claim that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines can develop mutations during production that may reduce their effectiveness, as immunogenicity is a key component of vaccine effectiveness. The document explicitly links egg-adapted changes to altered immune responses, substantiating the claim.
verified_evidence.original_relevance: This quote provides evidence that mutations arising from egg adaptation during vaccine production can significantly affect the immune response to certain influenza strains, supporting the claim that such mutations may reduce vaccine effectiveness.

verified_evidence.quote: Comparative immunogenicity studies and provide additional information to identify optimal vaccination strategies to prevent influenza. ... have reported that Q223R egg adapted change at the HA head domain of A (H1 N1) pdm09 virus can promote virus replication in eggs, alter antigenicity and influence immune response.
verified_evidence.explanation: The quote appears in two parts in the document. The first part, 'findings from comparative immunogenicity studies and provide additional information to identify optimal vaccination strategies to prevent influenza,' is found on page 11. The second part, 'have reported that Q223R egg adapted change at the HA head domain of A (H1 N1) pdm09 virus can promote virus replication in eggs, alter antigenicity and influence immune response,' is found on page 9. The factual content and technical details are preserved, though the two sentences are separated in the document.. The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that the Q223R egg-adapted mutation in the HA head domain of A (H1N1)pdm09 virus can arise during egg-based vaccine production, and that this mutation can alter antigenicity and influence the immune response. This demonstrates that mutations can develop during production and may impact vaccine effectiveness, which is the essence of the claim.
verified_evidence.presence_explanation: The quote appears in two parts in the document. The first part, 'findings from comparative immunogenicity studies and provide additional information to identify optimal vaccination strategies to prevent influenza,' is found on page 11. The second part, 'have reported that Q223R egg adapted change at the HA head domain of A (H1 N1) pdm09 virus can promote virus replication in eggs, alter antigenicity and influence immune response,' is found on page 9. The factual content and technical details are preserved, though the two sentences are separated in the document.
verified_evidence.support_explanation: The quote directly supports the claim. It explicitly states that the Q223R egg-adapted mutation in the HA head domain of A (H1N1)pdm09 virus can arise during egg-based vaccine production, and that this mutation can alter antigenicity and influence the immune response. This demonstrates that mutations can develop during production and may impact vaccine effectiveness, which is the essence of the claim.
verified_evidence.original_relevance: This quote references studies showing that specific egg-adapted mutations (like Q223R) can arise during production, altering the virus's antigenicity and the resulting immune response, which supports the claim about mutation development and its impact on effectiveness.

new_evidence.quote: Sequence analyses All the testing viruses used in this study were sequenced. Sequences were analyzed against the sequences of candidate vaccine viruses (CVV) of the study vaccines as deposited in Global Initiative on Sharing Avian Influenza Data (GISAID) database by BioEdit version 7.0.9.0 (Table 1).
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote shows that sequence analysis was performed to compare the viruses used in vaccines to reference strains, which is necessary to detect mutations that may arise during production, such as those that could occur in egg- or cell-based vaccine manufacturing.

new_evidence.quote: Egg grown A (H3 N2) viruses were propagated in 10 day old embryonated chicken eggs, cell grown A (H3 N2) viruses were propagated in stably transfected MDCK cells with c... A (H1 N1) pdm09 and influenza B viruses were propagated in Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells. ... Egg- and cell (MDCK)-propagated A/Michigan/45/2015 (H1 N1) pdm09, B/Colorado/06/2017 (B/Victoria), and B/Phuket/3073/2013 (B/Yamagata) viruses were tested in year 1, Egg propagated A/Brisbane/02/2018 (H1 N1) pdm09, cell propagated A/Idaho/7/2018 (H1 N1) pdm09, egg- and cell propagated B/Colorado/06/2017 (B/Victoria) and B/Phuket/3073/2013 (B/Yamagata) viruses ...
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote details the propagation of vaccine viruses in eggs and cell cultures, which is the process during which adaptive mutations can occur, supporting the claim that such mutations may develop during production.

new_evidence.quote: For A (H3 N2), RIV4 vaccination not only improved the quality of the functional neutralizing antibody ... However, for A (H1 N1) pdm09 and B viruses, the difference in HI antibody versus the total HA head binding antibody levels among 4 vaccine groups was less consistent suggesting that the magnitude of improvement differ
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote suggests that differences in immune response quality between vaccine types may be due to changes in the HA protein, which can result from mutations acquired during production in eggs or cells, thus potentially affecting effectiveness.

new_evidence.quote: Comparing pre- and 1 month post vaccination, A (H3 N2) HA stalk binding antibodies were significantly boosted in ccIIV4-RIV4, RIV4-RIV4, IIV4-ccIIV4, and IIV4-RIV4 arms, while A (H1 N1) pdm09 HA stalk binding antibodies were also significantly boosted in ccIIV4-ccIIV4 and RIV4-ccIIV4 arms (Fig. 8 C). However, fold rise in both A (H1 N1) pdm09 HA stalk and A (H3 N2) HA stalk antibodies were low (GM fold rise <1.78) with no significant difference (p > 0.05) among all 7 repeat vaccination arms (Fig 8 D) tion (C, D).
new_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote indicates that despite vaccination, the immune response to certain viral components was limited, which may be due to mutations in the HA protein that arise during egg or cell-based vaccine production, thus reducing effectiveness.
